transcript:
Patient: I've been trying to keep up with the Positive Data Log, but it's been challenging to remember to write things down when I'm feeling down. I did manage to write about the conversation I had with my friend from church, though.

Therapist: That's a great start, Emilio. It's understandable that it can be difficult to remember to write things down when you're feeling depressed. One strategy that can be helpful is to set aside a specific time each day to reflect on your experiences and write in your Positive Data Log. It could be right before bed or first thing in the morning, whatever works best for you. The key is to make it a consistent habit. Let's take a look at what you wrote about your conversation with your friend from church. What evidence did you record that challenges your negative core belief "I'm not good enough"?

Patient: I wrote that my friend seemed genuinely interested in what I had to say and that we had some common interests. I guess that shows that I am good enough to have meaningful conversations and connections with others.

Therapist: Absolutely, Emilio. That's a great example of evidence that challenges your negative core belief. It's important to remember that your worth isn't determined by your accomplishments or external factors. You have inherent value as a person, regardless of your perceived shortcomings. As we continue to accumulate evidence in your Positive Data Log, it will become easier to challenge your negative core beliefs and develop more balanced and helpful beliefs about yourself. Let's shift gears a bit and talk about your progress with exploring teaching certification programs. You mentioned that you've done some research but are feeling overwhelmed by the process. Can you tell me more about what's been challenging for you?

Patient: It's just a lot of information to take in, and I'm not sure where to start. I worry that I won't be able to keep up with the coursework or that I won't be able to find a job even if I do get certified.

Therapist: It's normal to feel overwhelmed when starting a new endeavor, especially one that involves a significant change like pursuing a new career path. Let's break down the process into smaller, more manageable steps. Have you identified any specific programs that interest you?

Patient: I've looked at a few online programs that seem promising, but I haven't reached out to any of them yet.

Therapist: Reaching out to programs for more information is a great next step. It can help you get a better sense of the requirements and whether the program is a good fit for you. What thoughts come up for you when you think about reaching out to a program?

Patient: I worry that they'll think I'm not qualified or that I'm too old to be starting a new career.

Therapist: Those are common concerns, but it's important to remember that many people change careers later in life and that your life experiences can be an asset in the classroom. Let's challenge those thoughts using the same process we used earlier. What would you say to a friend who expressed similar concerns?

Patient: I guess I would tell them that it's never too late to pursue your passions and that their life experiences could make them a great teacher.

Therapist: That's a great perspective, Emilio. Now, let's apply that same logic to your own situation. Is there evidence that you're not qualified or that your age would be a barrier to becoming a teacher?

Patient: I mean, I do have a Master's degree, and I have a lot of life experience. And I've always enjoyed helping others learn.

Therapist: Those are all great points, Emilio. Your education and life experience could be significant assets in the classroom. And your passion for helping others learn is a great foundation for a career in teaching. Let's set a goal for you to reach out to at least one program in the next week to request more information. We can use your thought records to challenge any negative thoughts that come up during the process. How does that sound?

Patient: That sounds manageable. I'll try to reach out to a program this week and see what information I can get.

Therapist: That's a great plan, Emilio. Remember, you don't have to make any decisions right away. Gathering information is an important first step, and we can continue to explore your options together. Let's also continue to monitor your progress with the thought records and Positive Data Log. Consistency is key, so try to set aside a specific time each day to work on these techniques. In our next session, we can review your progress and continue to work on challenging your negative beliefs and exploring your career goals. How are you feeling about our plan for the next week?

Patient: I'm feeling a bit more hopeful. It helps to break things down into smaller steps. I'll do my best to keep up with the thought records and Positive Data Log and reach out to a teaching program.

Therapist: That's great, Emilio. Remember, progress isn't always linear, and there may be setbacks along the way. The important thing is to keep practicing and not get discouraged if things don't go perfectly. I'm here to support you every step of the way. Let's continue to work together to challenge your negative beliefs and build a more fulfilling life for yourself.
